title: Thursday, 12th September 2019
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Hotels? Sure.

11:27 am
InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 5,023, down 144 (-2.79%), High: 5,071, Low: 4,977, Volume: 78.11k
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,423, down 121 (-2.66%), High: 4,530, Low: 4,402, Volume: 98.04k
Shinshin Nth Ireland court says Scotland wrong, Boris right
BE11:29am

Caz.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

We downgrade AC, IHG and WTB to UW as a combination of factors cause us to turn cautious on the risk-reward profile for the European hotel sector within our coverage universe, including: a lack of momentum, high consensus expectations, high multiples, late cycle, decelerating RevPAR, companyspecific concerns, a lack of catalysts and an uncertain macro environment. We also look at previous recessions and include our equity strategy and quant teams’ respective views to provide a comprehensive overview.

BE11:29am

(@Shinshin: it doesn't, though, because different laws.)

cracklenpop Any grey on Morrisons?
BE11:30am

Lack of momentum at the companies. The three hoteliers under our coverage lacked momentum in 1H, both at the underlying RevPAR level and on the profitability and CF front. We expect RevPAR and profits to fall short of market expectations and guidance in the second half of the year.
Lowering estimates below consensus. We are reducing RevPAR estimates across the board, impacting profitability, and setting MSD below consensus.

Valuation premium to disappear. We note that the share prices have remained resilient despite ongoing downgrades, whilst valuations are rich, sitting within or above historical multiples.

tangledodyssey Analysts got it wrong on Morrisons?
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Unsupportive investor feedback positioning lack of catalysts. The uncertain macro outlook, combined with high valuations and company-specific concerns (more evident at Accor and Whitbread than IHG), translates into low investor appetite to own these stocks and increasing short interest from low levels. We separately see no major positive company-specific catalysts looming either.

Late cycle. The current cycle is similar in length to the 1990s cycle, the longer of the last two cycles, and has seen higher cumulative RevPAR growth already. RevPAR is currently entirely driven by ADR and not occupancy, which is at peak levels. We believe that sooner rather than later, the market will incorporate end-of-cycle concerns into valuations and forecasts within the peer group. We note that our US counterparts (Joseph Greff & team) recently downgraded the sector on similar concerns, whilst European and US RevPAR cycles have historically been correlated.

BE11:31am

A brief recap of what happened during and in the run-up to the last recession offers some insight into investor sentiment at the current stage of the cycle, in our view. We note that for hotels during the last great
recession (2007-10), the market in the US and Europe started to price in end-of-cycle concerns 7-10 months in advance, whilst valuations and EPS contracted by 50% on avg.

BE11:32am

So, InterContinental's not a defensive and Whitbread is "the most exposed hotelier to the current economic and
political UK turmoil."

11:32 am
BE11:32am

That's the gist there.

undefined
BE11:32am

Morrison, then.

11:32 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 202.73, up 8.73 (+4.50%), High: 203.80, Low: 198.70, Volume: 3.18m
BE11:34am

Results okay rather than good. Special divi nice. Amazon expansion gives a headline for us types to write about.

BE11:34am

Investec to summarise.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

When issuing its Q120A IMS in May 2019, management tempered expectations for FY20, particularly noting that Q220 could
be weak given the strong comparative period in Q219A. Not unexpectedly, therefore, Morrisons has released a mixed set of
H120A numbers, where lower than expected revenue was more than balanced by stronger margins. The company reported
a 1.6% increase in underlying EPS to 6.38p (INVe 5.89p) from a 5.3% increase in underlying PBT to £198m (INVe £181m)
and 0.3% increase in revenue to £8.83bn (INVe £9.04bn)

BE11:35am

While Group LFL sales ex-fuel and ex-VAT were up 0.2%, this was much weaker than our expectations (INVe 2.4%), retail LFL revenue slipped 1.1% (INVe +0.4%) while wholesale grew 1.3% (INVe 2.1%). Fuel revenue remained flat over the period (INVe 2.1%). The company declared a 4.3% increase in the interim dividend to 1.93p (INVe 1.94p) and, as per last year, also declared a special interim dividend of 2.00p.

BE11:35am

In its FY19 results release, management kept the business outlook general, noting that the company has “many sales and profit growth opportunities ahead”. In its short Q120A IMS, it was also noted that growth will be “both meaningful and sustainable”. While no quantitative guidance was given other than on wholesale business targets, in its H120 statement management noted a “robust” profit performance in what was a period of unfavourable weather, lack of specific spending stimuli in H120 (unlike H119) and weak consumer confidence.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

They're buyers.

BE11:35am

While the company is having to work through a difficult trading period where weak consumer confidence in the current uncertain political and economic environment is compounded by strong comparative periods, we believe that the current degree of price weakness is unwarranted, trading as it does at an over 30% discount to its European supermarket peers.

BE11:36am

And Bernstein.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Key message: This is a good start to UK food retail H1 result season. LfL was a touch better, profits were nicely better (3.1%), and a dividend (inc special) that is 2% better. All that despite investing in competitiveness and pointing to a better H2. Doomsday will have to wait another year. We think this set up bodes well for the other grocers in coming weeks.

BE11:36am

And Shore.

BE11:36am

Morrisons has faced into a comparative challenging Q2 FY2020, where like-for-like (LFL) Retail sales fell by 2.4%, leading to a more subdued H1 PTP outcome than we anticipated in March 2019 but better than we forecast in July; Morrison reported H1 FY2020 PTP of £198m (Shore Capital [SC] forecast, £188m, consensus, £192m).

Accordingly, with a ‘nice’ beat to expectation, IFRS 16 compliant, we are pleased to be reiterating our FY2020 financial estimates following the issue of the Group's interim results.

Pleasingly, we note the 4.3% increase in the ordinary DPS and welcome the recurring special distribution (2.0p), which makes for a FY2020 dividend yield of 6.7%, paid from free cash flow - that is attractive and a yield that to us feels too high. Self-improvement continues, as does broadening and growing on a balanced and sustainable basis, the Group's well-framed mantras. In this respect we note the ‘multi-year partnership signed with Amazon extending relationship[s] in time and scope.’

Whilst domestic political chaos persists, all things being equal, we note management's considered confidence to continue growth, which should support a somewhat de-rated stock of mid-2019.

11:38 am
undefined

BE11:39am

Seems the ROTR have been stunned into silence. What else can we fill the hour with?

BE11:42am

Babcock, Trainline, bloody Hurricane and BAT.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Cool, we'll work through all of those.

BE11:43am

Starting with bloody Hurricane, which has a similar investor pool to Sirius.

BE11:43am

Huge excitement over the weekend when a flame appeared on top of its rig.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Today we get confirmation that the prospect is indeed producing oil, in decent amounts.

BE11:44am

Here's RBC.

BE11:44am

Hurricane has announced a positive well result from the Lincoln Crestal well (HUR 50%, Spirit Energy 50%), West of Shetland, and we expect the stock to do well today on this result.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The Lincoln Crestal well recorded a maximum stable flowrate of 9,800b/d with the use of electrical submersible pumps, and flowed at a rate of ~4,700b/d under natural conditions, with no formation water produced. The well was spudded on 12th July and drilled to a TD of ~1,780m, with a 720m horizontal section of fractured basement reservoir. This test rate is slightly lower than the production wells on Lancaster which flowed at ~14,500b/d with ESPs, but helps to derisk the ~604mbbl of 2C resources on Lincoln.

The well will now be suspended, with long-term gauges installed to test interference with future GWA wells. It is then planned to be tied-back to the Aoka Mizu FPSO, located on the Lancaster field, during 2020, subject to technical, regulatory and joint venture approvals. Fully derisked, we estimate Lincoln could be worth ~55p/share to Hurricane, however; at this early stage we include ~14p/share for Lincoln in our 121p/share total NAV for Hurricane, which we expect to be more firmly underpinned by today's result.

BE11:44am

The Transocean Leader semi-submersible rig will now move to the location for the third (and final planned) well in the 2019 GWA drilling programme, 'Warwick West'.

BE11:45am

And Berenberg.

cracklenpop Shore is Morrisons house broker.
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Our view: Hurricane Energy has passed yet another significant milestone in its quest to commercially de-risk and develop fractured-basement oil reserves in the UK. Lincoln, one of the accumulations in the Greater Warwick Area (GWA), has flowed at commercial rates, helping to derisk over 600mboe of resources. Hurricane offers transformational upside over the coming 12 months, in our view. We maintain our Buy rating.
● Details on the Lincoln Crestal well: Hurricane has drilled the Lincoln Crestal well to a total depth of 1.8km with a 720m horizontal section. It put the well on a drill-stem test (DST), achieving a maximum stable flow rate of 9.8kbpd using electrical submersible pumps (ESPs)
and natural flow of 4.7kbpd, with no formation water produced. The well will now be suspended as a potential future producer. The flow rate is lower than those of the two producing wells at Lancaster, which flowed at 11kbpd/14.5kbpd using ESPs and at 6.6/6.5kbpd on natural flow. Lincoln is, however, commercial nevertheless. We note that flow rates are usually constrained in a DST and both of the Lancaster wells flowed above 10kbpd on natural flow once they were linked to the FPSO (floating production storage and offloading) vessel.

BE11:46am

Next milestones on GWA: Hurricane and its 50% partner Spirit Energy are planning an early production scheme (EPS) with a one-well tie-back, scheduled for next year, to the Aoka Mizu FPSO that is currently used for the Lancaster EPS. As with Lancaster, we expect continuous production of at least six months before the partners consider a full-field development of Lincoln. By then, the Lancaster EPS will have been producing for over a year, giving Hurricane a better understanding of the productivity of fractured basements in the area more broadly. In addition, the partners would have drilled more wells on GWA to better understand the geology.
● Valuation of Lincoln and GWA in perspective: We currently carry a GWA tie-back at 6p/9p on, respectively, a risked/unrisked basis in our NAV at a chance of success of 75%. We also attribute 17p/33p of risked/unrisked value to a full-field development on Lincoln, with the total value for a full-field development of the broader GWA set at 27p/82p on a risked/unrisked basis. The upside is transformational relative to the current price of 45p. We note, however, that our estimates are based on flow rates of 10kbpd per well, which are slightly higher than the rates achieved at Lincoln so far.
● Key risks – pressure drop and water ingress: These are the two main risks for fractured basement developments, which require 6-12 months of continuous production before the operator can form a better understanding of the geology and well productivity. Encouragingly, production at Lancaster is now in its fourth month, with no water encountered so far. We await for further production data before derisking the GWA development in our NAV any further.
● Valuation: Our price target is derived using a risked NAV, with the Lancaster EPS net of financials forming the core NAV, and a full-field development of Lancaster and GWA offering contingent upside.

BE11:47am

And Stifel.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

We have yet to update our financial estimates but carry 5/11 p/shr risked/unrisked for the project in our Contingent NAV below.

BE11:48am

BE11:48am

Punting on oil exploration is so weird.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

BE11:50am

And to to Trainline.

11:50 am
Trainline PLC (TRN:LSE): Last: 475.00, up 27 (+6.03%), High: 488.00, Low: 457.50, Volume: 467.88k
BE11:51am

With a small bump to earnings.

BE11:51am

Peel Hunt to summarise.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Second print as a listed company and all going to plan. Net ticket sales outlook confirmed for the full year but given the better than expected performance of revenue optimisation strategies (including insurance, refunds, and advertising), the company is upgrading its revenue growth guide for the full year to “low-to-mid 20% range”. We increase our revenue by 2% to assume 22% revenue growth and, alongside strong EBITDA drop through and incremental marketing in international, our EBITDA goes up by 3%. Given the known unknowns, including the Williams Reviews (expected this autumn), the potential for Uber to expand its nascent train business, and “Reserve with Google” looking to make Google Maps even more useful for its customers, we retain our Hold recommendation.

BE11:52am

Don't understand Trainline at all. What's it for?

Viking1 REF , surely not !!!
fortyeight How about Labour's tenant right to buy at Government mandated price? What will this do to the growing institutional BTR sector? Will it lead to an immediate crisis in supply and actually harm people looking for somewhere to rent?
rw42 trainline was there for when the nationalrail.co.uk website used to suck. Not sure any more..
BE11:53am

What does it do better than the National Rail site? Do consumers even notice which one they're using? Why's it generating a rake on basically nothing?

cracklenpop @REF!mes sentiments exactement
11:53 am
BE11:53am

And why is that rake so huge? Advertising? Google search fu?

tangledodyssey And the City still loves McDonnell? Something in the water there?
BE11:54am

What kind of business is that? Really? Back to Peel Hunt.

BE11:54am

After reporting group net ticket sales of 20% in Q1 20, this morning the company has printed 19% for H1 20. This is split 15% for UK and 52% for International. We have 16% and 51%, respectively for the full year. The company has guided that Q2 is a more normalised growth rate given the Q1 comps from last year (including the Beast from the East). Revenue growth for the half of 29%, compares to our 19% for the full year. Also, a brief note, this morning (in line with IPO plans), the company has announced that Deputy Chair Brian McBride will succeed Doug McCallum as Chair.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

The gap between net ticket sales growth and revenue growth explained by strong revenue optimisation offerings (such as insurance, refunds, advertising) that are incremental to ticket sales and have performed ahead of expectations, and the growth of eTickets, making the app more attractive than some of the less complete offerings in the market. International was stronger than expected due to the launch of its own revenue optimisation offerings (flexible fees and multi-currency) performing ahead

tangledodyssey And the banning of bankers' bonuses?
BE11:55am

Why would I download an app to buy train tickets?

BE11:55am

As a result, the company is increasing its guidance for revenue to “low-to-mid 20% range”, implying a softer H2 due to the annualisation of new revenue streams that launched in H2 19. At the same time, the company has announced that some additional marketing investment will be needed internationally as it comes to the end of its re-platforming. As quite often happens with re-platformings: they take longer and cost more. But worth it in the long run, especially if the company looks to do further M&A to win outside of its home market: smoother and more seamless integrations. We increase our revenue by 2% to +22% growth (from +19%) growth for FY20 and, assuming a 70% EBITDA drop through and £2m for marketing, our EBITDA goes up by 3%.

rw42 Think there were also cases where trainline would tell you cases where it'd be cheaper to buy split tickets which national rail wouldn't do, not that i've ever bothered
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Numis also.

BE11:55am

A strong statement that ultimately ups top line guidance for the
year and we expect consensus upgrades. We expect to upgrade our adjusted PBT by c.5% to reflect stronger expected revenue performance, partially offset by an increase in marketing costs in the International business. We retain our ADD recommendation and 492p target.

undefined
11:57 am
BE11:58am

BAT job cuts. 2,300 out by Hogmanay.

BE11:58am

From a staff of 56,700 employees

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 3,091, up 48.27 (+1.59%), High: 3,152, Low: 3,054, Volume: 1.14m
NFC TBH - I do use trainline app because i find it easier for my commute And also convenient for buying an add-on for season ticket. Barriers to change are pretty low though - more habit than anything else (the ads in the middle of the listing of train times are a bit annoying though)
Soundbuy Trainline offers a mortgage facility to enable you to buy your ticket.....
11:59 am
BE11:59am

Focused on middle management. A fifth of the senior roles will be affected.

BE12:00pm

Liberum:

BE12:00pm

This is a sign of underperformance and the group is taking steps to sharpen its focus on growth whilst reducing the cost base. While there can be meaningful brain-drain in this process, if it helps BAT reach its goal of £5 billion revenues in New Categories by 2023/24, it would be worth it.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Who also have a bit on vaping.

BE12:00pm

Following the 2019 National Youth Tobacco Survey, the FDA is expected to take action in the coming weeks to put forth regulation to ban flavoured e-cigarettes. The survey showed an acceleration of what is being called a youth e-cigarette epidemic where 27.5% of high school students used e-cigarettes in the past 30 days. Interestingly, tobacco use continues to decline among high schoolers down to a new low of 5.8%, which brings into question the 'e-cigarettes are a gateway to tobacco use' thesis. This thesis will be tested as the FDA restricts the e-cigarette category. We expect some of these e-cigarette users to experiment with other flavoured tobacco products on the market like menthol cigarettes and potentially IQOS, thus helping the tobacco companies. The time frame for this ban could be 'several weeks' to put forth a plan, followed by a 30 day implementation period. It could be relatively speedy because the FDA is simply ending its enforcement discretion - in other words, the Obama era rules allowed e-cigarettes on the market at the FDA's discretion and the FDA has the ability to pull flavours. It seems that the FDA can pull these products off the market without a rulemaking process. Scott Gottlieb described banning flavours as the easier option from a legal perspective.. Tobacco flavoured e-cigarettes will remain on the market until May 2020, though that day might move forward. It is unclear how much the tobacco industry will even fight this legislation because it will probably help the sales of far more profitable cigarettes. We were surprised that the FDA didn't simply ban JUUL but if the FDA wants to ding them for this youth epidemic, they will not allow them to pass the May 2020 PMTA hurdle because of this youth issue. All e-cig manufacturers will need to demonstrate there is a net benefit to society from being on the market to clear PMTA. This hurdle is important because it should significantly reduce competition in e-cigarettes, thus helping the profitability of these products. We see this as more of a positive for BAT though we would like to see them file their PMTA for glo. While it is still positive for Imperial Brands, Imperial over-indexes to the vapour category vs its peers, so there is a case to be made that they do not benefit as much. Incidentally, this flavoured e-cig ban will probably have a negative impact on Imperial's LTIPs. Finally, all of this action is tying up the FDA's lawyers who are clearly bogged down and unable to advance the Nicotine standard rule, which is also a positive for tobacco companies.

Shinshin Do we care about the Clearstream thing potentially rippling back as tax demands and penalties into banks incl Barclays ?
BE12:02pm

Lots of cynicism about the FDA's attention paid to vaping based on five deaths and 450 cases of severe lung problems ......

Plato the Cook BAT, from the RNS: 'simplify all key business processes and "ways of working." ... planned to be substantially complete by January 2020'That is either hopelessly optimistic or the plan has no real substance.
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

.... which seems rather unfair given it's absolutely central to its remit.

tangledodyssey cannabis market coming fast for BAT and IMB?
BE12:04pm

Morgan Stanley:

BE12:04pm

Bottom Line: Spoken to the Company. Accelerated cost savings a positive step but widely expected (we already have £1bn of cost savings in our numbers 2020-4.). Given the newsflow yesterday on banning flavours in e-cigs we expect the focus to shift back onto menthol in combustibles and Maximum Nicotine. We view yesterday's positive stock price reaction as presenting another opportunity to exit this story. We remain Underweight BAT and continue to recommend treading cautiously in the tobacco sector. What has BAT announced this morning? BAT has announced the first major step in delivering the strategy CEO Jack Bowles set out at the beginning of the year. Making BAT stronger, simpler and faster while accelerating New Category growth. This morning the company outlined a cost savings plan which will 1) reduce management (over 20% of senior roles will be affected) 2) create fewer business units, 3) better leverage global services and 4) simplify the business overall. The plan is expected to be delivered by the end of Jan 2020 but no quantitative guidance has been given regarding the amount of cost savings. Our expectation is the majority will be reinvested to help deliver the £5bn revenue target in New Categories by 2023/24. Multiple Steps Needed to Address Debt Concerns…We downgraded BAT to Underweight in our recent report Industry Risk Navigator, arguing that the threat from a Maximum Nicotine Policy in the US isn’t reflected in the share price, that US regulation is a significant overhang and also highlighting the slow pace of deleveraging. We argued in our follow up report BAT - Relieving the Debt that taking multiple steps to address debt concerns (eg accelerated cost savings, asset sales and a dividend cut) could make us more constructive and provide the company more breathing room to invest in new products / categories at a time of rapid industry change.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Regulatory Overhang Remains Real…The FDA’s statement last night to remove non-tobacco e-cig flavours including mint and menthol is a significant step. We expect this step to renew focus on banning menthol in cigarettes, which former FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb discussed last November. In our report BAT – BAD for BATS we made clear that US menthol accounts for 25% of BAT group profits and why a proposal to ban menthol in combustible cigarettes would present a significant challenge. We continue to believe that regulatory risk on US tobacco remains heightened and that the threat of a Maximum Nicotine Policy isn’t reflected in the BAT share price. We expect more newsflow on Nicotine in October (according to the FDA’s own agenda).
